review_blob: kind of a confusing beer. pours black with a mixture of aromas: roast, spice, orange, chocolate. living proof that even an imperial stout cant bury all the weird flavors in a beer.

an interesting new brew, clear with lots of mango and citrus notes. solid malt backbone that dissolves nicely into the azacca bitterness. well done, althought i must admit that this apparently isnt my favorite variety of hops.

12 oz can - pours out amber with little carbonation and head. toffee and earthy notes in the nose with only a hint of hops to offer some balance. Its not overly sweet but there is definitely some residual sugars hanging around to do a nice job of masking the 10% abv. well done, probably the best barleywine ive had from a can (okay, thats not a good comparison) but still a nice brew. quite enjoyable on a crisp fall afternoon.

labeled as Czechvar here in the USA - quite a dark brew, darker than i expected. malty and toasty, clean with a good balance. not overly sweet despite the malt aroma, and very well put-together. excellent brew, well executed for the style.

from a 750 mL bottle, it pours out a shade of garnet with an off-white head. huge hops aroma, although i dont pick up anything particularly "dank" - lots of pine and pepper, some citrus. big bracing body that does well to hold up the hops bitterness. an even finish that doesnt particularly lean toward either hops or malt. nice brew, a solid variation on the theme of imperial IPA.
beer_name: Founders Backstage Series #13: reDANKulous Imperial Red IPA

review_blob: huge roasty and boozy aroma - the type of nose that tells you this beer could easily spend 10 more years in the bottle. dark liquid with thin tan head, and the first taste impressions are heat and syrupy roasted barley. hops bitterness offsets what must be a huge malt bill, overall this is a big burly brew. notes of spice and chocolate come and go amongst alcohol heat and classic imperial stout character. big brew from a big brewery.

classic oatmeal stout nose of roasted barley and sweet starchy oat - very dark approaching black, with a moderate amount of carbonation and head, perhaps a little much for a stout but not necessarily a detractor. reminiscent of Founders Breakfast Stout with a similar creamy and roasty mouthfeel although less coffee effect. nice brew, well done and definitely not the average "new brewery stout."

a very fruity and flowery smelling IPA althought not all that bitter - a nice pale gold color with appropriate carbonation and lacing. im surprised by the 7.5% abv as it doesnt present particularly hot, but it does dry out nicely as the lemony and oily hops traverse the palate. a nicely done brew but perhaps a bit tame as it lacks a certain punch. perhaps it could use just a bit more alpha bittering? otherwise enjoyable and a good offering from a new brewery.

kind of a kitchen sink approach to an imperial stout... results in a bit of a muddled nose, although some roasted malt and spiciness emerges. very dark liquid with relatively low carbonation, although it fizzes up somewhat on the tongue. peppery notes abound which provide a unique character to the style; its quite intriguing and i wonder what this will resemble after a few years of mellowing in the bottle. good today, but probably better tomorrow....
beer_name: Bells Planet Series: Neptune - The Mystic

review_blob: okay, so its a sour imperial stout from jolly pumpkin. certainly an unconventional approach, but lets see: very dark, almost black opaque with heavy oak and house JP notes in the aroma. little of the typical imperial stout character, but instead its a big roasty sour. interesting and enjoyable, but the tartness overwhelms much of the stout character resulting in somewhat of a jumbled take on either style. quite a niche beer, a kind of brew not suited for the masses but for those seeking it out. for its hefty price tag, im not sure its Leelanau aka Jolly Pumpkins best effort.

Surprisingly hoppy aroma out of the bottle, although I dont know why Im surprised. Citrus, vinous, dusty, and bitter, with only a note of malt backbone. More bracing hops, well-balanced hops effect without becoming one dimensional. Clean hoppy finish and overall this is an excellent beer.

Quite a difficult beer to get, even here in Bells home territory. Pours out a dark nearly black liquid with huge citrus hops aroma which almost buries the black roasted components. Orange and grapefruit loom, with just a hint of tannic dark acidity. Intriguing and complex, with a touch of alcohol heat apparent in the finish.
beer_name: Bells Planet Series: Uranus - The Magician

review_blob: from the corked 750mL bottle, it pours out a deep black and darker than expected. huge pillowy head tinted to tan with clove and spice aromas. saison acidity and darker tannic toast notes as well. an interesting beer inspired by a tv series that i very much enjoy - this brew does it justice.
beer_name: Ommegang Game of Thrones #5 - Three-Eyed Raven

review_blob: bottle says enjoy by 2014 end, and yet here we are in the middle of 2015 - the horrors. pours out a lovely amber with a fair amount of haze and a substantial off-white head. malt, fruit yeast notes, and eminently british elements comprise the nose. no hint of its relatively high 8.5% abv, and it embodies the british flavor profile as well - well balanced with a pleasant malt/hops interplay, and overall quite nice. fullers have another success.

kind of a murky tan color, tending toward amber with a very thin amount of mostly-white bubbles atop. strong bourbon notes - oak, vanilla, a touch of alcohol heat and plummy fruit character. not much in the way of hops or bitterness, but plenty of rich and big-bodied sugars: caramel, molasses, toffee. on the sweet side for a barrel aged barley wine, but its not necessarily a bad thing; i might characterize this is as an old ale rather than barley wine (whats the difference anyway?). clearly the best beer in the Planets lineup so far, and certainly the one that seems most true to its inspiration. i do wonder what this will taste like after a few years in the cellar....
beer_name: Bells Planet Series: Saturn - The Bringer Of Old Age

review_blob: 12 oz bottle pours out a dark near-black with a good amount of tan head. rich full aroma, with some whiskey notes and plenty of roasty cream character. for the high abv, theres not any noticeable alcohol heat and a nice full body to carry the huge array of flavor. quite a nice brew; the spicy rye is an intriguing touch and it ends up very enjoyable.

A pleasant smelling lager, and if I didnt know better I might say it reminds me of Bells lager of the lakes. Crisp clean malt profile, well-rested with no off flavors. Nicely balanced and quite enjoyable. Better than the UPA certainly, and a brew I hope to enjoy again.

a nicely balanced moderately-hopped beer. pours out of the 12 oz bottle as a slightly cloudy gold, brightly headed liquid. malty and clean, although im not sure the toasted malt is entirely appropriate as it lends a bit of sweetness and tannin that feels just a touch out of place. enjoyable enough, and i wish this new brewer good luck.

Hazy amber pours out of the 12 oz bottle with a big spicy hops and malt aroma. Beige head sits atop, with maybe a hint of alcohol heat. Very reminiscent of Bigfoot or other hoppy american barley wines, with a crisper hoppier finish than many of those. A nice big brew.

Pours a nice clearish straw color, with a green tropical hops aroma. Pale malt background for a nice hoppy and medium bodied brew, clean finish with a nice balance of abv and heat. Creamy and bitter aftertaste with a pleasant lingering hoppiness.

malt and hay, along with some yeast tartness and bready sourdough notes. light-bodied, tending toward thin and although it has more character than light beer, its really a weak offering as far as saison goes. its enjoyable enough but a bit of a miss overall.
beer_name: Odd Side Ales Aint No Sunshine When Saison

review_blob: far more belgian character than i expected - which isnt necessarily a criticism. to be fair, i was expecting more of a Chouffe Dobbelen which seems to introduce only an initiation of belgian yeast but this beer is its own. a nice copper color with sticky white head, a touch of ester and molasses behind some nice hops additions. sort of an odd combination of dubbel/tripel/ipa that doesnt really work for me in the way that some belgian IPAs have before.

a light amber with a very slightly off-white head. big aroma of green hops; citrus (specifically orange and pineapple), grass, wood and earth - quite nice and eminently IIPA. medium body which does well to cover its strong 9% and a clean hoppy finish. very solid brew with a lingering sweetness that outlasts the hops finish.

from the 12 oz bottle, its an orange-amber color with heavy orange and grapefruit aroma. where does the 8.2% live? it is nicely hopped without excess alcohol heat, and a big presence of hops over top a malt backbone throughout. i suppose that "mandarina" hops must be named for mandarin orange character... it fits. a very nice brew, but perhaps bigger than an everyday option.

Purchased as a 12 oz single, mostly because its St Patricks Day. Big roast and deep hazy black with not a huge alcohol nose. Huge chocolaty body with oaty starchy character and not much hops other than whats required to even out a ton of malt. Nice thick stout which goes down smooth, perfect for today.
beer_name: Shorts Moher Export Irish Imperial Stout

review_blob: Brown murky ale, light on fizz with a small thin tan head. Not a heavy aroma but bread, toast, nuts and wood are present. Thinner and hotter than the aroma suggests; some alcohol brightness present throughout. Medium to full body at the finish as some sugars linger. A nice brew, not sure how Jupiter particularly inspired this but worth the experience.
beer_name: Bells Planet Series: Jupiter - The Bringer Of Jollity

review_blob: Pours out of the 12 oz bottle as a nice garnet or ruby with a bit of off-white head. Malt, brown sugar and dark fruit and alcohol aroma, not overly impressive but indicative of the style anyway. A relatively middling quad, which is not to say its bad; its merely another drinkable Belgian.

On draft in a snifter, nice aroma of dusty yeast and citrusy hops, with good pale malt backbone - like a Danish Orval without the mystique, which is quite a compliment. Clean even finish with a lingering bitterness and just enough brett to be present without becoming over-tart.

trippy logo on the 12 oz bottle, i suppose that could be a vertigo trigger?... it pours out blackish and not quite opaque, with heavy notes of roast and malt. up front it seems to lack some finesse in exchange for large amounts of barley, roasted barley, and hops - perhaps overly tannic and roasty. beyond that it seems to be a typical imperial stout in terms of body and alcohol, and except for some heavy-handedness is an otherwise decent brew. not bad but im glad it was a single and not a six-pack.

750 ml courtesy of a friend with an English friend. A classic tripel appearance and nose, cloudy and yeasty, easy carbonation and a fluffy whitish head. Some alcohol heat underneath straw and pale malt, with grassy light hops. A nice brew, it seems like the UK may have figured a nice approximation of Belgian beer.

a complicated aroma floats over a reddish pink brew with a not-quite-tan head. notes of fruit, citrus, raisin, spicy yeast and a standoff between sticky malt and sticky hoppy resin. quite nice, indicative of what belgian yeast can turn an otherwise only-moderately-interesting beer into. solid beer, hopefully they continue this line.

from a 22 oz bomber, it pours out a chocolatey brown like a porter should, with a hint of smoke and some other tangy/spicy elements that are hard to pin down. chipotle character is more apparent in the flavor, although to call the heat even "mild" is an overstatement - its more of a peppery element than anything spicy or hot. it becomes a little more acidic throughout the lifetime of the glass with a rougher finish. decent i guess.

a pricey 12 oz bottle but its a special, so i guess its worth a shot? pours out quite dark and murky with a rich aroma of red wine and bourbon ahead of any typical scotch ale character. maybe a hint of alcohol heat but certainly not hot, and there is ever-so-slightly more carbonation than i expected from the style. big rich malt and bourbon dominate, the oak comes through as well but not as dominatingly as in the nose. big sweet finish that is done nicely, and i would probably have pegged this as an Old Ale rather than scotch but theres enough there that well go with that. a nice brew but really a one-time purchase.
beer_name: Arcadia Barrel Aged Loch-Up Scotch Ale

review_blob: another crapshoot from shorts - this time its a ChaiPA. The bottle pours out a dark brown liquid with tan bubbles atop. heavily spiced aroma, mostly ginger, clove, other winter-style spices. some roasty chocolate as well, but it hides behind the spices. medium body and smooth mouthfeel, a decent brew for being experimental. not for me but worth a taste.

surprise surprise, another pale ale with a goofy name from shorts. that doesnt mean that my expectations are lower or anything, just that its yet another beer to try and keep track of. a nice green hops aroma with a mild creamy body, light and expressive with thinner reminders that its not a high-alcohol brew. a nicely done pale ale, despite being frustratingly indifferentiable from its many siblings at shorts.

seems to be an unconventional marriage of characteristics between pale ale and red wine, but sometimes great things come from unexpected combinations and indeed, hope springs eternal. however, the name doesnt quite inspire greatness - was it named before or after it was brewed? it pours out a nice lighter-than-copper orange with light carbonation, and an aroma that seems muddled between woody tannins and vinous earthy hops. it seems a solid endeavor but i really think that the "red wine" barrels used for this beer would have had better effect on an Old Ale or bigger, maltier style than a pale ale. all in all its enjoyable but kind of an inefficient use of money and beer.

somehow listed currently as a Dubbel but i suppose there isnt any single way to characterize this beer as an individual style. dark amber with a curiously large number of aromas: hops, allspice/clove/nutmeg, toast, raisin and others. Its surprisingly not as heavy as many christmas ales - all in all, this brew has left me entirely confused as to how it should even be considered, based on its presentation. its tasty and unique, so perhaps thats enough.

a nice brew, i guess another IPA from shorts? light amber color, citrus and pine nose and just a touch more malt body than some other IPAs. hides its abv quite well as it feels nearly like a session brew.

out of the 12 oz bottle, its a dark viscous liquid. murky, woody brown color with a thin ring of light tan head; very few bubbles. sweet dark-and-dried fruits dominate, and other notes of red wine and molasses. overall a sweet brew with just a hint of greenish hops to offer a little contrast to the residual sugars. a nice brew, most enjoyable on a cold night.

not so obviously a stout; id call it more of a porter at first glance and smell. a very dark ruby with rather simplistic aroma of roasted coffee bean and sugar. fairly acidic and not overly sweet but not quite brash. surprisingly bitter finish which seems to be a combination of high alpha hops and burnt coffee. certainly not a bad beer but seems to be a poor impersonation of certain other stouts from the state of michigan.

quite a nice brew - hefty price tag but i suppose that comes with the territory for barrel aged imperial stouts. very dark brown, essentially opaque with only a thin presence of carbonation and head. strong aroma of roasted barley and oaky vanilla, not much alcohol heat despite its 9.5% and plenty of coffee/mocha as well. a touch astringent which belies the sweetish aroma somewhat, although it might just be an overabundance of roasted barley and roasted coffee, almost overextracted. enjoyable, and very well done; certainly dont mind this as an occasional seasonal stout!

a nice brew out of the bottle. dark amber color and enjoyable hops aroma, blended with oak and tannins. easy-to-drink and light-bodied enough to drink regularly, definitely a strongly flavored session pale ale.

"malt beverage", hmm. exotically spiced, clearly a blonde with definite witbier notes. lots going on, making it difficult to pick out individual aromas and flavors although there is a some dominant apricot above the other essences. an interesting medley of flavors, and reasonably light-bodied and dry for a relatively high ABV. a touch of acidity as well, which might turn off some drinkers but i enjoy it.
beer_name: Bells Planet Series: Venus - The Bringer Of Peace

review_blob: pours out a nice brown color, nose reminiscent of a belgian dubbel with a bit less yeast character. orange is not so apparent but just the hint is a nice accent, which triggers just the slightest reminder of wassail. medium to sweet body and finish with plenty of residual sugar, which is not necessarily bad as a christmastime seasonal. a nice brew overall but certainly not one for regular consumption...

ahh, idiocracy - a fine movie. out of the 12 oz bottle, straw and sourdough notes dominate, a golden hazy liquid with light carbonation and little head. more dough and toast in the body and some nice floral hops to keep things in check. nicely balanced but leaning towards a little alcohol heat, lacking a crispness that many pilsners have - perhaps from just a touch too much sweetness? a pretty decent brew regardless.
Sweet wheat aroma with herbal sweetness, which I would have attributed to honey if I didnt know it was agave. Wheaty and starchy with little hops presence. Decent but not my thing.

well, this looks like a weird one, and often times i end up disappointed with shorts weird forays into the exotic ends of beer. definite mango nose with subdued mint; i wonder if this bottle isnt especially fresh? tropical sweetness and a touch of mint acidity and tang but i wouldnt have picked mint as a primary characteristic. nicely balanced and refreshing with a medium-to-full body - not a disappointment but nothing id label as more than experimental.

a lovely brew - pours a copper golden color with a simultaneously hoppy and bright yeast nose. malt and orval notes sit above an intense liquid. no brett but this exhibits complex character, almost enough to question if this is some sort of dry-hopped and rebottled orval. i hope this stays on as a regular from Shorts.

a nice brew in a cool bottle (although part of its price tag clearly went to packaging) - definitely a hybrid, with characteristics of baltic porter and imperial stouts. tons of blackened and caramel malt with enough hops that its not oversweet, and it has a nice mellow full body. quite nice.

how now brown cow, how now brown cow. a fun name for a seasonal brown ale, plenty of toasted malt and caramel malt notes with a little bit of greenish hops to even out a touch. a pretty decent brew and quite nice in the autumn.
beer_name: Odd Side Ales How Now Brown Cow
